details.Technical Details:
AppCheck detected a possible IDOR vulnerability within the target application.


**Rationale**

Under normal operation the value **1** was submitted via the **query.filters[search]** parameter. The following potentially sensitive data was identified within the page:

**Data Type/Description:**
 Response Data was returned where one or more properties, field names or data types match a keyword (first_name, forename, surname, last_name, given_name, family_name, familyname, firstname, lastname, givenname, nationalinsurance, socialsecuritynumber, addressContactName, contactname, customername, dateofbirth, vehicleRegistration, CreditCardType, CreditCardNo, CreditCardExpiry, CreditCardHolderName, CreditCardSecurityNo, username, address, givename) or data type.

| Potentially Sensitive Data                                                                 |

data.description:
Insecure direct object references (IDOR) is a type of access control vulnerability whereby the attacker is able to
access restricted data by manipulating a client supplied identifier. For example, consider an application that loads
a users profile information using a URL such as *https://website/profile?user_id=50*. In this example, the supplied
user_id value directly references the user profile in the backend database. A IDOR vulnerability occurs when the
attacker is able to change the supplied value to access another users data, e.g. https://website/profile?user_id=51.

IDOR vulnerabilities can occur for a variety of reasons including direct database references, predictable file names
and other cases where the attacker is able to manipulate a reference value to bypass access controls.

From OWASP Top 10 2013 (part or Broken Access Control in later versions):

*A direct object reference occurs when a developer exposes a reference to an internal implementation object, such
as a file, directory, or database key. Without an access control check or other protection, attackers can
manipulate these references to access unauthorized data*.

**Note:** This finding may be a false positive if the application permits access to the identified data by design.

**References**

*   [[https://www.troyhunt.com/owasp-top-10-for-net-developers-part-4/]]

*   [[https://wiki.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Insecure_Direct_Object_References_(OTG-AUTHZ-004)]]

data.solution: Ensure proper access controls are enforced to prevent direct access to restricted data.

data.description:
Insecure direct object references (IDOR) is a type of access control vulnerability whereby the attacker is able to
access restricted data by manipulating a client supplied identifier. For example, consider an application that loads
a users profile information using a URL such as *https://website/profile?user_id=50*. In this example, the supplied
user_id value directly references the user profile in the backend database. A IDOR vulnerability occurs when the
attacker is able to change the supplied value to access another users data, e.g. https://website/profile?user_id=51.

IDOR vulnerabilities can occur for a variety of reasons including direct database references, predictable file names
and other cases where the attacker is able to manipulate a reference value to bypass access controls.

From OWASP Top 10 2013 (part or Broken Access Control in later versions):

*A direct object reference occurs when a developer exposes a reference to an internal implementation object, such
as a file, directory, or database key. Without an access control check or other protection, attackers can
manipulate these references to access unauthorized data*.

**Note:** This finding may be a false positive if the application permits access to the identified data by design.

**References**

*   [[https://www.troyhunt.com/owasp-top-10-for-net-developers-part-4/]]

*   [[https://wiki.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Insecure_Direct_Object_References_(OTG-AUTHZ-004)]]

data.title: jQuery End of Life (EOL) Detection - Linux

details.Impact: An EOL version of jQuery is not receiving any security updates   from the vendor. Unfixed security vulnerabilities might be leveraged by an attacker to compromise   the security of this host.
details.Detection: Checks if an EOL version is present on the target host.

data.solution: It is recommended to disable the deprecated TLSv1.0 and/or   TLSv1.1 protocols in favor of the TLSv1.2+ protocols. Please see the references for more   information.
data.title: SSL/TLS: Deprecated TLSv1.0 and TLSv1.1 Protocol Detection

details.Impact:
An attacker might be able to use the known cryptographic flaws   to eavesdrop the connection between clients and the service to get access to sensitive data   transferred within the secured connection.

Furthermore newly uncovered vulnerabilities in this protocols won't receive security updates   anymore.
details.Detection: Check the used TLS protocols of the services provided by this   system.
details.Technical Details:
::

    In addition to TLSv1.2+ the service is also providing the deprecated TLSv1.0 and TLSv1.1 protocols and supports one or more ciphers. Those supported ciphers can be found in the 'SSL/TLS: Report Supported Cipher Suites' (OID: 1.3.6.1.4.1.25623.1.0.802067) VT.
details.External Sources:
The following external sources can help provide some more information on this vulnerability

 * [[https://ssl-config.mozilla.org/]]
 * [[https://bettercrypto.org/]]
 * [[https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8996/]]
 * [[https://vnhacker.blogspot.com/2011/09/beast.html]]
 * [[https://web.archive.org/web/20201108095603/https://censys.io/blog/freak]]
 * [[https://www.enisa.europa.eu/publications/algorithms-key-size-and-parameters-report-2014]]
details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

 * CVE-2011-3389
 * CVE-2015-0204

data.description:
It was possible to detect the usage of the deprecated TLSv1.0   and/or TLSv1.1 protocol on this system.

The TLSv1.0 and TLSv1.1 protocols contain known cryptographic   flaws like:

- CVE-2011-3389: Browser Exploit Against SSL/TLS (BEAST)

- CVE-2015-0204: Factoring Attack on RSA-EXPORT Keys Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy   Encryption (FREAK)
data.synopsis: It was possible to detect the usage of the deprecated TLSv1.0   and/or TLSv1.1 protocol on this system.

data.solution:
The following mitigation possibilities are available:

1. Disabling HTTP compression

2. Separating secrets from user input

3. Randomizing secrets per request

4. Masking secrets (effectively randomizing by XORing with a random secret per request)

5. Protecting vulnerable pages with CSRF

6. Length hiding (by adding random number of bytes to the responses)

7. Rate-limiting the requests

Note: The mitigations are ordered by effectiveness (not by their practicality - as this may differ   from one application to another).
data.title: SSL/TLS: BREACH attack against HTTP compression

details.Impact: The flaw makes it easier for man-in-the-middle attackers to   obtain plaintext secret values.
details.Detection:
Checks if the remote web server has HTTP compression enabled.

Note: Even with HTTP compression enabled the web application hosted on the web server might not   be vulnerable. The low Quality of Detection (QoD) of this VT reflects this fact.
details.Technical Details:
::

    Based on the following information it was determined that the remote web server has HTTP compression enabled:
    
    HTTP headers : Content-Encoding: gzip
    URL          : https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/.well-known/
details.External Sources:
The following external sources can help provide some more information on this vulnerability

 * [[http://breachattack.com/]]
 * [[http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/987798]]
 * [[http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2013/08/07/1]]
 * [[https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=995168]]
 * [[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_compression]]
details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

 * CVE-2013-3587

data.description:
SSL/TLS connections are vulnerable to the 'BREACH' (Browser   Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive Compression of Hypertext) attack.

Angelo Prado, Neal Harris and Yoel Gluck reported that SSL/TLS   attacks are still viable via a 'BREACH' (Browser Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive   Compression of Hypertext) attack, which they describe as:

While CRIME was mitigated by disabling TLS/SPDY compression (and by modifying gzip to allow for   explicit separation of compression contexts in SPDY), BREACH attacks HTTP responses. These are   compressed using the common HTTP compression, which is much more common than TLS-level   compression. This allows essentially the same attack demonstrated by Duong and Rizzo, but without   relying on TLS-level compression (as they anticipated).

It is important to note that the attack is agnostic to the version of TLS/SSL, and does not   require TLS-layer compression. Additionally, the attack works against any cipher suite. Against a   stream cipher, the attack is simpler: The difference in sizes across response bodies is much more   granular in this case. If a block cipher is used, additional work must be done to align the output   to the cipher text blocks.
data.synopsis: SSL/TLS connections are vulnerable to the 'BREACH' (Browser   Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive Compression of Hypertext) attack.

data.solution: Update to the latest version.

details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

- CVE-2020-7656

data.description: jquery prior to 1.9.0 allows Cross-site Scripting attacks via the [[code:load()]] method. The [[code:load()]] method fails to recognize and remove "[[code:<script>]]" HTML tags that contain a whitespace character, i.e: "[[code:</script >]]", which results in the enclosed script logic to be executed.

data.solution: Update the affected libraries. See the references section for further information.

data.description:
An outdated JavaScript library was detected.  The presence of a vulnerable library does not necessarily mean that
the application is vulnerable, however the library could allow a vulnerability to be introduced even when secure
code practices are followed.

In some cases, the library may expose vulnerable components (including unused features) that are readily
exploitable, in others, specific code patterns would need to be used.

This finding is reported to highlight components that should be updated to prevent vulnerabilities being introduced
into otherwise secure code.


**Note:** AppCheck imports vulnerability data to check for outdated libraries at the beginning of each scan. One
of the (optional) vulnerability sources is the NPM database, this includes NodeJS libraries that can be implemented
within both the browser, and server-side. Typically, the impact of a server side implementation is far greater than
when exploited within the browser. In some cases, the vulnerability may only be exploitable when used server side,
but the CVE for the vulnerability is attached to the library version without this distinction.

Many of the flaws reported by this module have active checks that do not rely on version checking and will be
reported as separate findings should they be readily exploitable on your application.

data.title:
Outdated jquery library detected: Versions of jquery prior to 1.9.0 are vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting. The load method fails to recognize and remove "<script>" HTML tags that contain a whitespace character, i.e: "</script >", which results in the enclosed script logic to be executed. This allows attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript in a victim's browser.


## Recommendation

Upgrade to version 1.9.0 or later. (CVE-2020-7656)

data.description:
An outdated JavaScript library was detected.  The presence of a vulnerable library does not necessarily mean that
the application is vulnerable, however the library could allow a vulnerability to be introduced even when secure
code practices are followed.

In some cases, the library may expose vulnerable components (including unused features) that are readily
exploitable, in others, specific code patterns would need to be used.

This finding is reported to highlight components that should be updated to prevent vulnerabilities being introduced
into otherwise secure code.


**Note:** AppCheck imports vulnerability data to check for outdated libraries at the beginning of each scan. One
of the (optional) vulnerability sources is the NPM database, this includes NodeJS libraries that can be implemented
within both the browser, and server-side. Typically, the impact of a server side implementation is far greater than
when exploited within the browser. In some cases, the vulnerability may only be exploitable when used server side,
but the CVE for the vulnerability is attached to the library version without this distinction.

Many of the flaws reported by this module have active checks that do not rely on version checking and will be
reported as separate findings should they be readily exploitable on your application.

data.solution:
The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting
sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. 

If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the
application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session
handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted
over unencrypted communications.
data.title: SSL Cookie Without Secure Flag Set

details.Affected Cookie: default_login_throttle=%5B%5D; expires=Wed, 17 Apr 2024 03:24:52 GMT; Max-Age=300; path=/; domain=members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com; HttpOnly

data.description:
If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the
cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby
preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker
monitoring network traffic. 

If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in
clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An
attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links,
either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued
the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an
attacker may be able to use links of the form [[code:http://example.com:443/]] to
perform the same attack.

details.Impact:
An attacker might be able to use the known cryptographic flaws   to eavesdrop the connection between clients and the service to get access to sensitive data   transferred within the secured connection.

Furthermore newly uncovered vulnerabilities in this protocols won't receive security updates   anymore.

data.description:
It was possible to detect the usage of the deprecated TLSv1.0   and/or TLSv1.1 protocol on this system.

The TLSv1.0 and TLSv1.1 protocols contain known cryptographic   flaws like:

- CVE-2011-3389: Browser Exploit Against SSL/TLS (BEAST)

- CVE-2015-0204: Factoring Attack on RSA-EXPORT Keys Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy   Encryption (FREAK)
data.synopsis: It was possible to detect the usage of the deprecated TLSv1.0   and/or TLSv1.1 protocol on this system.

data.solution:
The following mitigation possibilities are available:

1. Disabling HTTP compression

2. Separating secrets from user input

3. Randomizing secrets per request

4. Masking secrets (effectively randomizing by XORing with a random secret per request)

5. Protecting vulnerable pages with CSRF

6. Length hiding (by adding random number of bytes to the responses)

7. Rate-limiting the requests

Note: The mitigations are ordered by effectiveness (not by their practicality - as this may differ   from one application to another).
data.title: SSL/TLS: BREACH attack against HTTP compression

details.Impact: The flaw makes it easier for man-in-the-middle attackers to   obtain plaintext secret values.
details.Detection:
Checks if the remote web server has HTTP compression enabled.

Note: Even with HTTP compression enabled the web application hosted on the web server might not   be vulnerable. The low Quality of Detection (QoD) of this VT reflects this fact.

data.description:
SSL/TLS connections are vulnerable to the 'BREACH' (Browser   Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive Compression of Hypertext) attack.

Angelo Prado, Neal Harris and Yoel Gluck reported that SSL/TLS   attacks are still viable via a 'BREACH' (Browser Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive   Compression of Hypertext) attack, which they describe as:

While CRIME was mitigated by disabling TLS/SPDY compression (and by modifying gzip to allow for   explicit separation of compression contexts in SPDY), BREACH attacks HTTP responses. These are   compressed using the common HTTP compression, which is much more common than TLS-level   compression. This allows essentially the same attack demonstrated by Duong and Rizzo, but without   relying on TLS-level compression (as they anticipated).

It is important to note that the attack is agnostic to the version of TLS/SSL, and does not   require TLS-layer compression. Additionally, the attack works against any cipher suite. Against a   stream cipher, the attack is simpler: The difference in sizes across response bodies is much more   granular in this case. If a block cipher is used, additional work must be done to align the output   to the cipher text blocks.
data.synopsis: SSL/TLS connections are vulnerable to the 'BREACH' (Browser   Reconnaissance & Exfiltration via Adaptive Compression of Hypertext) attack.

**Official Fix & Remediation Guidance**

Customers are advised to upgrade to the latest version of the impacted software or platform.

NOTE: Remediation of this vulnerability by patching to a specific version indicated may not be sufficient to secure the product against further vulnerabilities discovered in later versions, subsequent to the publication of this guidance. Unless contra-indicated, customers are therefore advised to always upgrade to the latest version of the product available.

**Temporary Mitigation & Workarounds**

(The vendor has not advised of any alternative temporary mitigation or workarounds)

NOTE: Caution should always be taken in applying any temporary mitigations listed. Mitigations are only recommended in cases where patches to remediate the vulnerability are not available, or cannot safely be applied to a given environment immediately. A given mitigation may not in all cases be recommended officially by the application vendor. The viability of any given temporary mitigation measure may vary, depending on server platform and existing configuration. Mitigations listed may incompletely remediate any given vulnerability. Configuration changes to implement listed mitigations may impact/disrupt required functionality within a given customer application. Care should therefore be taken to carefully analyse any listed mitigations for appropriateness to a given environment. Customers are advised to test any configuration changes prior to their being introduced into a production environment.

data.description:
**Background & Context**

TLS is an internet standard to secure the communication between servers and clients on the internet, for example that of web servers, FTP servers, and Email servers. This is possible because TLS was designed to be application layer independent, which allows its use in many diverse communication protocols.

**Vulnerability Summary**

ALPACA is an application layer protocol content confusion attack, exploiting TLS servers implementing different protocols but using compatible certificates, such as multi-domain or wildcard certificates.  A MiTM attacker having access to victim's traffic at the TCP/IP layer can redirect traffic from one subdomain to another, resulting in a valid TLS session. This breaks the authentication of TLS and cross-protocol attacks may be possible where the behavior of one protocol service may compromise the other at the application layer.

The software does not protect the source or destination IP and port address of TCP connections established using TLS. If two or more  servers implement different protocols (e.g. HTTP and SMTP) but  offering encryption using TLS with certificates that are valid for both servers (such as multi-domain or wildcard certificates) , then a Man in the Middle (MiTM) attacker can redirect traffic from one subdomain to another, establishing a valid TLS session to a different destination host than the remote client intended. 

**Impact If Exploited**

A suitably positioned MitM attacker could lead the victim to an attacker-controlled website that triggers a cross-origin HTTPS request with a specially crafted  payload. The attacker then redirects the request to a server that has a certificate compatible with the web server. The attack could then either download a stored malicious JavaScript file from, or reflect malicious JavaScript contained in the request. In both cases, the JavaScript code is executed in the context of the targeted web service.

**Affected Product Versions**

* Sendmail versions prior to release 8.17
* vsftpd prior to version 3.0.4,
* nginx prior to release 1.21.0



**References**

* [[https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975623]]

* [[https://alpaca-attack.com/]]

* [[https://lists.debian.org/debian-lts-announce/2022/11/msg00031.html]]

data.solution:
If possible do not trust host values submitted via these headers when processing within the application.

The exact fix will depend on the reason these headers are used/supported in the first place. Often the "X-Forwarded-"
group of headers are used by proxy servers when the "host" header may be changed along the path.

From [[https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-Host]]:

    *"Host names and ports of reverse proxies (load balancers, CDNs) may differ from the origin server handling
    the request, in that case the X-Forwarded-Host header is useful to determine which Host was originally used.*

When this is the case, and when this header must be processed for legitimate reasons, validate the supplied value
against a list of known good host headers.

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable Cache Poisoning Attacks. In some cases, the injected URL component
may be included within password reset URLS (or similar) and allow them to be manipulated to point to the attackers'
server.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

data.solution:
If possible do not trust host values submitted via these headers when processing within the application.

The exact fix will depend on the reason these headers are used/supported in the first place. Often the "X-Forwarded-"
group of headers are used by proxy servers when the "host" header may be changed along the path.

From [[https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-Host]]:

    *"Host names and ports of reverse proxies (load balancers, CDNs) may differ from the origin server handling
    the request, in that case the X-Forwarded-Host header is useful to determine which Host was originally used.*

When this is the case, and when this header must be processed for legitimate reasons, validate the supplied value
against a list of known good host headers.

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable Cache Poisoning Attacks. In some cases, the injected URL component
may be included within password reset URLS (or similar) and allow them to be manipulated to point to the attackers'
server.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

data.solution: Update to the latest version.
data.title: JQuery < v1.9.0 - Cross Site Scripting ('XSS') Vulnerability in Load Method (CVE-2020-7656)

details.Technical Details: Detected [[members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com]]:0 - jquery jquery 1.8.2
details.External Sources:
The following external sources can help provide some more information on this vulnerability

* [[https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20200528-0001/]]

* [[https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-JQUERY-569619]]

* [[https://supportportal.juniper.net/s/article/2021-07-Security-Bulletin-Junos-OS-Multiple-J-Web-vulnerabilities-resolved-in-Junos-OS-21-2R1?language=en_US]]

* [[https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/cpujul2022.html]]
details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

- CVE-2020-7656

data.description: jquery prior to 1.9.0 allows Cross-site Scripting attacks via the [[code:load()]] method. The [[code:load()]] method fails to recognize and remove "[[code:<script>]]" HTML tags that contain a whitespace character, i.e: "[[code:</script >]]", which results in the enclosed script logic to be executed.

data.solution:
Review the sandbox configuration for the iframe listed in the details section.

In general:
 * Ensure that only the minimum capabilities required are granted to the iframe.
 * Ensure that conflicting tokens are removed, leaving the desired token.
 * Ensure all tokens are valid and non-experimental.
data.title: IFrame Sandbox Audit

details.Technical Details:
**The following iframe was identified within the response:**


::

    <iframe id="x"></iframe>


The iframe does not include the [[code:sandbox]] attribute.

data.description:
The sandbox attribute, when specified, enables a set of extra restrictions on any content hosted by the iframe.
Several case sensitive tokens can be specified within this attribute's value to grant capabilities to the
iframe which would otherwise be blocked by use of the sandbox attribute. By utilising the sandbox attribute and
granting the minimum capabilities required for the content to function correctly, it is possible to reduce the
likelihood of exploitation via a malicious iframe.

The principle of least privilege dictates that only the minimum privileges/capabilities required to perform
correctly should be granted. For example, if plugins are not required, the iframe should not have support for
plugins. This applies equally to both first and third party content.

Note potentially hostile files should not be served from the same server as the file containing the iframe
element. Sandboxing hostile content is of minimal help if an attacker can convince the user to just visit the
hostile content directly, rather than in the iframe. To limit the damage that can be caused by hostile HTML
content, it should be served from a separate dedicated domain. Using a different domain ensures that scripts in the
files are unable to attack the site, even if the user is tricked into visiting those pages directly, without the
protection of the sandbox attribute.
data.synopsis: The use of the sandbox attribute in iframes loaded by the target was audited.

data.solution:
Implement HSTS. The following resource provides a guide on how to implement HSTS on a variety of platforms:

[[https://www.globalsign.com/en/blog/what-is-hsts-and-how-do-i-use-it/]]
data.title: Strict Transport Security not enabled on some pages

details.Technical Details:
The Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) header security header was found for some pages but not others.

For example, the following pages did not return the security header:

data.description:
The assessed HTTPS application does not enforce HTTP Strict Transport Security allowing connections over clear
text connections. Even if the site redirects users from HTTP to HTTPS, it is not enforced by the  browser.
This provides a window of opportunity for a suitably placed attacker to intercept and downgrade all connections
to the site, tools such as SSLStrip can be used to automate this process.

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web server directive that informs web browsers only use HTTPS when
connecting to the site.

Data submitted over an unencrypted connection are vulnerable to interception by an attacker who is suitably
positioned on the network. This includes the user's own network, within their ISP and within the application's
hosting infrastructure.
data.synopsis:

to the site, tools such as SSLStrip can be used to automate this process.

data.title: Security Headers Report
data.description:
Several security headers have been introduced in recent years to help mitigate certain attacks against web
applications. This finding reports the result of an audit against the most common headers.

See the Technical Details section for a description of audited header.
data.synopsis:
Several security headers have been introduced in recent years to help mitigate certain attacks against web
applications. This finding reports the result of an audit against the most common headers.

data.solution: Review the domains which are allowed by the CORS policy in relation to any sensitive content within the application.
data.title: HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (Wildcard *)
data.description:
The application implements an HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) policy which allows access from any domain.
Permitting access from any origin could present a security risk unless the affected application hosts only
unprotected public content.

Web browsers include a security control (Same Origin Policy) to prevent a
malicious web page from making requests to and reading responses from other
websites. Without the same origin policy, a malicious website could make
requests to sensitive websites on behalf of the user and submit the
response back to the attacker. The Same Origin Policy prevents a malicious
script from reading responses unless the scheme, hostname and port number
match, thereby assumed to be part of the same website.

Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a mechanism to white-list a server
so that the browser is allowed to read responses to permit applications to be
spread across different hostnames without the Same Origin Policy
restriction. CORS is enabled through server response headers, where the
"access-control-allow-origin" header determines which websites are allowed
to read responses, and the "access-control-allow-credentials" header
determines if the browser can use authenticated requests (cookies).

For requests that do not require authentication, a wildcard of "*" can be
used.  In this case any website can make a request and read the response,
but it cannot send along the user's cookie or authentication headers, which
in many cases would be needed to access sensitive user data. However, there
are some cases where the use of a wild card could post a risk:

- A CORS wildcard could allow an externally loaded malicious website to
  make connections to a restricted application on an internal network and
  read responses. In some cases a restricted application may serve data
  that is not intended for public consumption, even without authentication.
data.synopsis:
The application implements an HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) policy which allows access from any domain.
Permitting access from any origin could present a security risk unless the affected application hosts only
unprotected public content.

data.solution:
You should review the application functions that are accessible at the listed URL(s), and determine whether
they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a
framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

Consider implementing Content Security Policy (CSP), a built-in protection mechanism in web browsers that allows you
to specify trusted sources for content such as JavaScript and allows you to block inline incudes. It can effectively
stop attacks such as Cross-site Scripting and ClickJacking. The settings are configured server side and given to the
web browser via a server response header, the "Content-Security-Policy" header. The header specifies a whitelist of
resources which are approved for content, 'resources' covers a multitude of things including but not limited to frames,
JavaScript, and fonts.

data.description:
It may be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the affected application (or specific pages)
within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may allow a "clickjacking" attack whereby the attacker's page overlays
the target application with a different interface designed to trick the user into performing unwanted actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options
header in order to prevent framing attacks.

The first 10 instances of this flaw are reported (typically this flaw affects all URLS)
data.synopsis:
It may be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the affected application (or specific pages)
within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may allow a "clickjacking" attack whereby the attacker's page overlays
the target application with a different interface designed to trick the user into performing unwanted actions.

data.solution:
To disable TCP timestamps on linux add the line   'net.ipv4.tcp_timestamps = 0' to /etc/sysctl.conf. Execute 'sysctl -p' to apply the settings at   runtime.

To disable TCP timestamps on Windows execute 'netsh int tcp set global timestamps=disabled'

Starting with Windows Server 2008 and Vista, the timestamp can not be completely disabled.

The default behavior of the TCP/IP stack on this Systems is to not use the Timestamp options when   initiating TCP connections, but use them if the TCP peer that is initiating communication includes   them in their synchronize (SYN) segment.

See the references for more information.
data.title: TCP Timestamps Information Disclosure

details.Impact: A side effect of this feature is that the uptime of the remote   host can sometimes be computed.
details.Detection: Special IP packets are forged and sent with a little delay in   between to the target IP. The responses are searched for a timestamps. If found, the timestamps   are reported.
details.Technical Details:
::

    It was detected that the host implements RFC1323/RFC7323.
    
    The following timestamps were retrieved with a delay of 1 seconds in-between:
    Packet 1: 143670440
    Packet 2: 143671825

- CVE-2019-11358

data.description:
jQuery before 3.4.0, as used in Drupal, Backdrop CMS, and other products, mishandles [[code:jQuery.extend(true, {}, ...)]] because of [[code:Object.prototype]] pollution. If an unsanitized source object contained an enumerable [[code:__proto__ property]], it could extend the native [[code:Object.prototype]].

The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype.

By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the product depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as [[code:hasOwnProperty()]], [[code:toString()]] or [[code:valueOf()]]).

This weakness is usually exploited by using a special attribute of objects called proto, constructor or prototype. Such attributes give access to the object prototype. This weakness is often found in code that assigns object attributes based on user input, or merges or clones objects recursively.

data.description:
An outdated JavaScript library was detected.  The presence of a vulnerable library does not necessarily mean that
the application is vulnerable, however the library could allow a vulnerability to be introduced even when secure
code practices are followed.

In some cases, the library may expose vulnerable components (including unused features) that are readily
exploitable, in others, specific code patterns would need to be used.

This finding is reported to highlight components that should be updated to prevent vulnerabilities being introduced
into otherwise secure code.


**Note:** AppCheck imports vulnerability data to check for outdated libraries at the beginning of each scan. One
of the (optional) vulnerability sources is the NPM database, this includes NodeJS libraries that can be implemented
within both the browser, and server-side. Typically, the impact of a server side implementation is far greater than
when exploited within the browser. In some cases, the vulnerability may only be exploitable when used server side,
but the CVE for the vulnerability is attached to the library version without this distinction.

Many of the flaws reported by this module have active checks that do not rely on version checking and will be
reported as separate findings should they be readily exploitable on your application.
data.synopsis:
An outdated JavaScript library was detected.  The presence of a vulnerable library does not necessarily mean that
the application is vulnerable, however the library could allow a vulnerability to be introduced even when secure
code practices are followed.

data.solution:
Review scripts loaded from external hosts to ensure each is being loaded from a trusted third-party. Where possible,
implement Subresource Integrity to ensure the loaded script contains expected content and has not been manipulated.

See: [[https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Subresource_Integrity]]

Alternatively make a copy of known good scripts and host them on the application server (or elsewhere within your
own domain).

data.description:
When an application includes a script from an external domain, the script is executed within the security context
of the invoking application. The script can therefore perform any action that the application's own scripts can do,
such as accessing application data and performing actions within the context of the current user session.

When you include a script from an third party domain, you are trusting that provider with the data and functionality
of your application. If the attacker is able to modify the script hosted by the third-party, this script could then
attack users of your application.

**Important Note:** AppCheck identifies scripts by loading each page within a web browser, therefore dynamic scripts
such as those used by analytics services will be detected but may not be visible using "view source" on the page.

The iframe does not include the [[code:sandbox]] attribute.

data.description:
The sandbox attribute, when specified, enables a set of extra restrictions on any content hosted by the iframe.
Several case sensitive tokens can be specified within this attribute's value to grant capabilities to the
iframe which would otherwise be blocked by use of the sandbox attribute. By utilising the sandbox attribute and
granting the minimum capabilities required for the content to function correctly, it is possible to reduce the
likelihood of exploitation via a malicious iframe.

The principle of least privilege dictates that only the minimum privileges/capabilities required to perform
correctly should be granted. For example, if plugins are not required, the iframe should not have support for
plugins. This applies equally to both first and third party content.

Note potentially hostile files should not be served from the same server as the file containing the iframe
element. Sandboxing hostile content is of minimal help if an attacker can convince the user to just visit the
hostile content directly, rather than in the iframe. To limit the damage that can be caused by hostile HTML
content, it should be served from a separate dedicated domain. Using a different domain ensures that scripts in the
files are unable to attack the site, even if the user is tricked into visiting those pages directly, without the
protection of the sandbox attribute.
data.synopsis: The use of the sandbox attribute in iframes loaded by the target was audited.

data.solution:
Review the sandbox configuration for the iframe listed in the details section.

In general:
 * Ensure that only the minimum capabilities required are granted to the iframe.
 * Ensure that conflicting tokens are removed, leaving the desired token.
 * Ensure all tokens are valid and non-experimental.
data.title: IFrame Sandbox Audit

data.description:
The sandbox attribute, when specified, enables a set of extra restrictions on any content hosted by the iframe.
Several case sensitive tokens can be specified within this attribute's value to grant capabilities to the
iframe which would otherwise be blocked by use of the sandbox attribute. By utilising the sandbox attribute and
granting the minimum capabilities required for the content to function correctly, it is possible to reduce the
likelihood of exploitation via a malicious iframe.

The principle of least privilege dictates that only the minimum privileges/capabilities required to perform
correctly should be granted. For example, if plugins are not required, the iframe should not have support for
plugins. This applies equally to both first and third party content.

Note potentially hostile files should not be served from the same server as the file containing the iframe
element. Sandboxing hostile content is of minimal help if an attacker can convince the user to just visit the
hostile content directly, rather than in the iframe. To limit the damage that can be caused by hostile HTML
content, it should be served from a separate dedicated domain. Using a different domain ensures that scripts in the
files are unable to attack the site, even if the user is tricked into visiting those pages directly, without the
protection of the sandbox attribute.
data.synopsis: The use of the sandbox attribute in iframes loaded by the target was audited.

data.solution:
Review the sandbox configuration for the iframe listed in the details section.

In general:
 * Ensure that only the minimum capabilities required are granted to the iframe.
 * Ensure that conflicting tokens are removed, leaving the desired token.
 * Ensure all tokens are valid and non-experimental.

data.description:
The application implements an HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) policy which allows access from any domain.
Permitting access from any origin could present a security risk unless the affected application hosts only
unprotected public content.

Web browsers include a security control (Same Origin Policy) to prevent a
malicious web page from making requests to and reading responses from other
websites. Without the same origin policy, a malicious website could make
requests to sensitive websites on behalf of the user and submit the
response back to the attacker. The Same Origin Policy prevents a malicious
script from reading responses unless the scheme, hostname and port number
match, thereby assumed to be part of the same website.

Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a mechanism to white-list a server
so that the browser is allowed to read responses to permit applications to be
spread across different hostnames without the Same Origin Policy
restriction. CORS is enabled through server response headers, where the
"access-control-allow-origin" header determines which websites are allowed
to read responses, and the "access-control-allow-credentials" header
determines if the browser can use authenticated requests (cookies).

For requests that do not require authentication, a wildcard of "*" can be
used.  In this case any website can make a request and read the response,
but it cannot send along the user's cookie or authentication headers, which
in many cases would be needed to access sensitive user data. However, there
are some cases where the use of a wild card could post a risk:

- A CORS wildcard could allow an externally loaded malicious website to
  make connections to a restricted application on an internal network and
  read responses. In some cases a restricted application may serve data
  that is not intended for public consumption, even without authentication.
data.synopsis:
The application implements an HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) policy which allows access from any domain.
Permitting access from any origin could present a security risk unless the affected application hosts only
unprotected public content.

data.solution:
You should review the application functions that are accessible at the listed URL(s), and determine whether
they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a
framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

Consider implementing Content Security Policy (CSP), a built-in protection mechanism in web browsers that allows you
to specify trusted sources for content such as JavaScript and allows you to block inline incudes. It can effectively
stop attacks such as Cross-site Scripting and ClickJacking. The settings are configured server side and given to the
web browser via a server response header, the "Content-Security-Policy" header. The header specifies a whitelist of
resources which are approved for content, 'resources' covers a multitude of things including but not limited to frames,
JavaScript, and fonts.

data.description:
It may be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the affected application (or specific pages)
within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may allow a "clickjacking" attack whereby the attacker's page overlays
the target application with a different interface designed to trick the user into performing unwanted actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options
header in order to prevent framing attacks.

The first 10 instances of this flaw are reported (typically this flaw affects all URLS)
data.synopsis:
It may be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the affected application (or specific pages)
within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may allow a "clickjacking" attack whereby the attacker's page overlays
the target application with a different interface designed to trick the user into performing unwanted actions.

data.solution:
The application should return caching directives instructing browsers not to store local copies of any sensitive
data. Often, this can be achieved by configuring the web server to prevent caching for relevant paths within the
web root. Alternatively, most web development platforms allow you to control the server's caching directives from
within individual scripts.

In some browsers [[code:Cache-Control: No-cache]] has also started behaving like the [[code:no-store]] directive.
To be on the safer side, we recommend that you use both [[code:no-cache]] and [[code:no-store]] when serving
sensitive pages.

Ideally, the web server should return the following HTTP headers in all responses containing sensitive content::

    Cache-control: no-store, no-cache;
    Expires: 0;
    Pragma: no-cache

Note: The HTML meta tag http-equiv attribute can be used to simulate an HTTP response header.  If the name attribute
is set, the http-equiv attribute should not be set.
data.title: Cacheable HTTPS Response

data.description:
Unless directed otherwise, browsers may store a locally cached copy of content received from web servers.
Some browsers, including Internet Explorer, cache content accessed via HTTPS. If sensitive information in
application responses is stored in the local cache, then this may be retrieved by other users who have access
to the same computer at a future time.

**Cache-Control: No-store**

This is the most secure of the cache-control directives. It tells the browser not only not to cache the page,
but also not to even store the page in its cache folder. Whenever you're serving a sensitive page, this is the cache
control directive to use.

**Cache-Control: No-cache**

Though this directive sounds like it is instructing the browser not to cache the page, there's a subtle difference.
The [[code:no-cache]] directive, according to the RFC, tells the browser that it should revalidate with the server
before serving the page from the cache. Revalidation is an optimisation technique that lets the application conserve
bandwidth. If the page the browser has cached has not changed, the server just signals that to the browser and the
page is displayed from the cache.

Hence, the browser (in theory, at least), stores the page in its cache, but displays it only after revalidation with
the server. In practice, IE and Firefox have started treating the no-cache directive as if it instructs the
browser not to even cache the page.

See the following URL for more details:

[[https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Logout_and_Browser_Cache_Management_(OWASP-AT-007)|Browser Cache Management]]
data.synopsis:
Unless directed otherwise, browsers may store a locally cached copy of content received from web servers.
Some browsers, including Internet Explorer, cache content accessed via HTTPS. If sensitive information in
application responses is stored in the local cache, then this may be retrieved by other users who have access
to the same computer at a future time.

data.solution:
Implement HSTS. The following resource provides a guide on how to implement HSTS on a variety of platforms:

[[https://www.globalsign.com/en/blog/what-is-hsts-and-how-do-i-use-it/]]

data.description:
The assessed HTTPS application does not enforce HTTP Strict Transport Security allowing connections over clear
text connections. Even if the site redirects users from HTTP to HTTPS, it is not enforced by the  browser.
This provides a window of opportunity for a suitably placed attacker to intercept and downgrade all connections
to the site, tools such as SSLStrip can be used to automate this process.

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web server directive that informs web browsers only use HTTPS when
connecting to the site.

Data submitted over an unencrypted connection are vulnerable to interception by an attacker who is suitably
positioned on the network. This includes the user's own network, within their ISP and within the application's
hosting infrastructure.

text connections. Even if the site redirects users from HTTP to HTTPS, it is not enforced by the  browser.
This provides a window of opportunity for a suitably placed attacker to intercept and downgrade all connections
to the site, tools such as SSLStrip can be used to automate this process.

data.solution:
To disable TCP timestamps on linux add the line   'net.ipv4.tcp_timestamps = 0' to /etc/sysctl.conf. Execute 'sysctl -p' to apply the settings at   runtime.

To disable TCP timestamps on Windows execute 'netsh int tcp set global timestamps=disabled'

Starting with Windows Server 2008 and Vista, the timestamp can not be completely disabled.

The default behavior of the TCP/IP stack on this Systems is to not use the Timestamp options when   initiating TCP connections, but use them if the TCP peer that is initiating communication includes   them in their synchronize (SYN) segment.

See the references for more information.
data.title: TCP Timestamps Information Disclosure

details.Impact: A side effect of this feature is that the uptime of the remote   host can sometimes be computed.
details.Detection: Special IP packets are forged and sent with a little delay in   between to the target IP. The responses are searched for a timestamps. If found, the timestamps   are reported.
details.Technical Details:
::

    It was detected that the host implements RFC1323/RFC7323.
    
    The following timestamps were retrieved with a delay of 1 seconds in-between:
    Packet 1: 3922979706
    Packet 2: 3922981334
details.External Sources:
The following external sources can help provide some more information on this vulnerability

 * [[https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1323]]

 * [[https://web.archive.org/web/20151213072445/http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=9152]]
 * [[https://www.fortiguard.com/psirt/FG-IR-16-090]]

The iframe does not include the [[code:sandbox]] attribute.

data.description:
The sandbox attribute, when specified, enables a set of extra restrictions on any content hosted by the iframe.
Several case sensitive tokens can be specified within this attribute's value to grant capabilities to the
iframe which would otherwise be blocked by use of the sandbox attribute. By utilising the sandbox attribute and
granting the minimum capabilities required for the content to function correctly, it is possible to reduce the
likelihood of exploitation via a malicious iframe.

The principle of least privilege dictates that only the minimum privileges/capabilities required to perform
correctly should be granted. For example, if plugins are not required, the iframe should not have support for
plugins. This applies equally to both first and third party content.

Note potentially hostile files should not be served from the same server as the file containing the iframe
element. Sandboxing hostile content is of minimal help if an attacker can convince the user to just visit the
hostile content directly, rather than in the iframe. To limit the damage that can be caused by hostile HTML
content, it should be served from a separate dedicated domain. Using a different domain ensures that scripts in the
files are unable to attack the site, even if the user is tricked into visiting those pages directly, without the
protection of the sandbox attribute.
data.synopsis: The use of the sandbox attribute in iframes loaded by the target was audited.

data.description:
The [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute specifies how the browser should handle the cookie in cross-site requests.
It is intended to mitigate cross site information leakage and some protection against cross-site request forgery
attacks.

To be considered the same site, the scheme and the domain (excluding sub domain) must match. For example
[[code:https://www.example.com]], [[code:https://foobar.example.com]], [[code:https://example.com]],
and [[code:https://example.com:8080] are the same site, however [[code:http://www.example.com]] is a different
site.
This is an important distinction from same origin (where the scheme, domain, and port must match), since any
vulnerability allowing the execution of attacker controlled JavaScript can be abused to bypass site based defences
such as the [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute.

The [[code:SameSite]] attribute may be set to [[code:Lax]], [[code:Strict]], or [[code:None]], if unspecified the
default is [[code:Lax]].

**Lax**

Browsers will send the cookie in cross-site requests which have the [[code:GET]] method and where triggered by a
top level navigation by the user (e.g. clicking a link). The cookie is not sent in cross-site [[code:POST]]
requests or background requests (e.g. from image references, iframes, or scripts).

Note that some web servers and frameworks will accept [[code:POST]] or [[code:GET]] requests which can be abused
to bypass this protection, it is therefore important to verify that only [[code:POST]] requests are accepted for
requests that modify state or data (in line with best practices) before relying on this cookie attribute.

**Strict**

Browsers will not send the cookie in any cross-site requests. This is the recommended option for any cookies that
permit authenticated access to resources as it is the most secure option, however it may negatively impact the user
experience in cases where cross-site functionality is intended.

**None**

Browsers will send the cookie in all cross-site requests no matter how the request was triggered or which site
triggered the request. This is the least secure option and the default behaviour of browsers before the
introduction of the [[code:SameSite]] attribute, leaving the site more susceptible to cross site attacks and
leakage.
There are some instances where [[code:SameSite:None]] is desirable such as when the cookie is intended to be used
from a third party context and doesn't grant any privileges.
Note for the [[code:SameSite:None]] attribute to be effective the [[code:Secure]] attribute must also be specified.
data.synopsis:
The [[code:SameSite=None]] cookie attribute instructs the browser to send the cookie in all cross site requests.
This can leave the application more vulnerable to cross-site attacks such as cross site request forgery.

data.solution:
Review the usage of cookies with the [[code:SameSite=None]] attribute to determine if they can be set to
[[code:SameSite=Strict]] or [[code:SameSite=Lax]] to take advantage of the more rigorous security the browser then
provides.

data.description:
The [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute specifies how the browser should handle the cookie in cross-site requests.
It is intended to mitigate cross site information leakage and some protection against cross-site request forgery
attacks.

To be considered the same site, the scheme and the domain (excluding sub domain) must match. For example
[[code:https://www.example.com]], [[code:https://foobar.example.com]], [[code:https://example.com]],
and [[code:https://example.com:8080] are the same site, however [[code:http://www.example.com]] is a different
site.
This is an important distinction from same origin (where the scheme, domain, and port must match), since any
vulnerability allowing the execution of attacker controlled JavaScript can be abused to bypass site based defences
such as the [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute.

The [[code:SameSite]] attribute may be set to [[code:Lax]], [[code:Strict]], or [[code:None]], if unspecified the
default is [[code:Lax]].

**Lax**

Browsers will send the cookie in cross-site requests which have the [[code:GET]] method and where triggered by a
top level navigation by the user (e.g. clicking a link). The cookie is not sent in cross-site [[code:POST]]
requests or background requests (e.g. from image references, iframes, or scripts).

Note that some web servers and frameworks will accept [[code:POST]] or [[code:GET]] requests which can be abused
to bypass this protection, it is therefore important to verify that only [[code:POST]] requests are accepted for
requests that modify state or data (in line with best practices) before relying on this cookie attribute.

**Strict**

Browsers will not send the cookie in any cross-site requests. This is the recommended option for any cookies that
permit authenticated access to resources as it is the most secure option, however it may negatively impact the user
experience in cases where cross-site functionality is intended.

**None**

Browsers will send the cookie in all cross-site requests no matter how the request was triggered or which site
triggered the request. This is the least secure option and the default behaviour of browsers before the
introduction of the [[code:SameSite]] attribute, leaving the site more susceptible to cross site attacks and
leakage.
There are some instances where [[code:SameSite:None]] is desirable such as when the cookie is intended to be used
from a third party context and doesn't grant any privileges.
Note for the [[code:SameSite:None]] attribute to be effective the [[code:Secure]] attribute must also be specified.
data.synopsis:
The [[code:SameSite=None]] cookie attribute instructs the browser to send the cookie in all cross site requests.
This can leave the application more vulnerable to cross-site attacks such as cross site request forgery.

data.description:
This plugin lists data stored by the browser within local databases such as localStorage, sessionStorage and
IndexedDB.

Local databases such as localStorage, sessionStorage and IndexedDB were not designed to be secure databases
and as such offer no security features. Data stored within these databases could be accessed by JavaScripts
running within the page including those injected via a Cross-Site Scripting Attack or imported from a third party.
data.synopsis:
This plugin lists data stored by the browser within local databases such as localStorage, sessionStorage and
IndexedDB.

server.

data.solution:
The robots.txt file is not itself a security threat, and its correct use can represent good practice for
non-security reasons. You should not assume that all web robots will honor the file's instructions. Rather, assume
that attackers will pay close attention to any locations identified in the file. Do not rely on robots.txt to
provide any kind of protection over unauthorized access.
data.title: robots.txt File

details.Summary: The web server contains a robots.txt file.

data.description:
The file robots.txt is used to give instructions to web robots, such as search engine crawlers, about locations
within the web site which robots are allowed, or not allowed, to crawl and index.  The presence of the robots.txt
does not in itself present any kind of security vulnerability. However, it is often used to identify restricted or
private areas of a site's contents. The information in the file may therefore help an attacker to map out the
site's contents, especially if some of the locations identified are not linked from elsewhere in the site. If the
application relies on robots.txt to protect access to these areas, and does not enforce proper access control over
them, then this presents a serious vulnerability.

data.solution:
When collecting Personally identifiable information from the user the following guidelines were provided by the UK's
Information Commissioners Office (ICO)

**Consent & Privacy Statement**

Ensure that you include a clear privacy statement that includes the the specific reason data will be stored. Consent
should be clear gained through positive opt-in.

*   Consent means offering individuals real choice and control. Genuine consent should put individuals in charge,
    build customer trust and engagement, and enhance your reputation.

*   Check your consent practices and your existing consents. Refresh your consents if they don't meet the GDPR
    standard.

*   Consent requires a positive opt-in. Don't use pre-ticked boxes or any other method of default consent.

*   Explicit consent requires a very clear and specific statement of consent.

*   Keep your consent requests separate from other terms and conditions.

*   Be specific and 'granular' so that you get separate consent for separate things. Vague or blanket consent is
    not enough.

*   Name any third party controllers who will rely on the consent.

*   Make it easy for people to withdraw consent and tell them how.

*   Keep evidence of consent - who, when, how, and what you told people.

*   Keep consent under review, and refresh it if anything changes.

*   Avoid making consent to processing a precondition of a service.

*   Public authorities and employers will need to take extra care to show that consent is freely given, and should avoid
    over-reliance on consent.


[[https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/lawful-basis-for-processing/consent/]]
data.title: GDPR: Possible PII form detected

details.Technical Details:
A form found at https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/podauth/newuser appears to collect personally identifiable information (PII) from the user.

 **Form Page:** https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/podauth/newuser

**Form Target:** https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/podauth/newuser/new

**Parameters:** user, first_name, last_name, school, email, dob[day], dob[month], dob[year]

data.description:
A form that appears to collect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) was detected. This does not constitute a
specific vulnerability, but rather is reported to aid in GDPR readiness and compliance.

AppCheck identifies PII collection forms based on the input fields and text within the form. Forms with several
text fields including inputs that request email addresses are flagged. False positives are minimised by ignoring
authentication and password reset forms. However occasionally false positives may occur. This happens when a form
matches the rule defined within this check but is not actually collecting PII data from the user. If this is the
case here, setting the finding to "False Positive" within the Workflow tab will remove it from the report and prevent
it being flagged in future scans.
data.synopsis:
A form that appears to collect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) was detected. This does not constitute a
specific vulnerability, but rather is reported to aid in GDPR readiness and compliance.

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable cache poisoning attacks.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

data.solution:
You should review the disclosed data to determine if it is sensitive and accessible in a way that should be
restricted and if so take appropriate steps to secure the data.
data.title: Possible Sensitive Data Disclosure (PII Data)

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable cache poisoning attacks.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

may help alleviate the problem.

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable cache poisoning attacks.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

data.solution:
You should review the disclosed data to determine if it is sensitive and accessible in a way that should be
restricted and if so take appropriate steps to secure the data.

data.description:
The application appears to support HTTP headers that can be used to override parts of the request URL, potentially
affecting processing of the request.

In some cases, these headers can be used to bypass protection systems and could be used to forge log entries.

If a caching system is in use this may enable cache poisoning attacks.
data.synopsis: A header typically used for overriding key HTTP Request variables appears to be supported.

data.solution: See technical details section.

# PyroCMS Community Edition

* [Website](http://pyrocms.com/)
* [Documentation](http://pyrocms.com/docs)
* [License](http://pyrocms.com/legal/license)
* [Forums](http://pyrocms.com/forums)
* Version: 2.1.4

## Team

* [Adam Fairholm](http://parse19.com/)
* [Jerel Unruh](http://unruhdesigns.com/)
* [Phil Sturgeon](http://philsturgeon.co.uk/)
* [Scott Parry](http://ikreativ.com/)

## Description

PyroCMS is a CMS built using the CodeIgniter PHP framework. Using an MVC architecture
it was built with modularity in mind. Lightweight, themeable and dynamic.

PyroCMS Community Edition is free to use, redistribute and/or modify for any purpose whether personal or commercial however you must retain the copyright in your source code and in the footer of the administration.


## Installation

Run http://example.com/installer to run the web-based installation script.


## Upgrading

For a detailed upgrade guide please look at the [2.0 Upgrading Documentation](http://www.pyrocms.com/docs/2.0/getting-started/upgrading-within-2.0).

## Bugs & Feature Requests

[Issue tracker](http://github.com/pyrocms/pyrocms/issues)
[Forum](http://www.pyrocms.com/forums)

Before reporting bugs or requesting any features, please check that it does not already exist.

## Git Structure

We use the git-flow model to structure our branches. This means you won't see a lot of activity on the master branch besides releases.
Most of the magic happens in the develop branch.
[More about git-flow](http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/)

It's strongly recommended that you download the [git-flow client](https://github.com/nvie/gitflow) and "publish" each feature branch you would like to see merged into the core. This way all features are not version-dependant and you can make as many changes as you like without needing them all to be merged in order.

data.title: Subdomain Takeover Audit
data.description:
External resources were audited for Subdomain and Service Take over vulnerabilities. This finding lists the audited
domains that were assessed during this scan.


**Subdomain Takeover Background**

A 'Subdomain Takeover' vulnerability typically arises when a resource such as a JavaScript is loaded from an external
domain which becomes publicly available (often unexpectedly) and can be hijacked by another party. There are two
different classes of Subdomain Takeover, each with a different underlying cause. The following scenarios describe
the most common cases:

**CNAME / DNS Takeover**

A Web site with a domain name of appcheck.com uses a CNAME record to another domain, for example::


            static.appcheck.com       CNAME       cndserver.otherdomain.com


At some point in time, otherdomain.com expires and is available for registration by anyone. Since the CNAME
record is not removed from then appcheck.com DNS zone, anyone who registers otherdomain.com has full control over
shop.appcheck.com until the DNS record is updated.


**External Service / CDN Takeover**

Modern web applications often make use of Content Delivery Networks (CDN) and thrid-party service provides in
order to deploy static content, integrate services, improve bandwidth efficiency and provide protection against
DDoS attacks. Since the CDN or service resides on a different domain, most providers offer the ability to delegate
via CNAME. For example, consider a website with the address www.appcheck.com has an integrated shop provided by
Shopify at https://appcheckshop.myshopify.com. To allow users to deploy services with a more friendly recognisable
name, Shopify (and many others) allow their services to be accessed by creating a CNAME record that points to the
hosted service. For example::


            shop.appcheck.com       CNAME       appcheckshop.myshopify.com


Now the user is able to access the resource at https://shop.appcheck.com which Shopify is configured to recognise
as the shop configured at appcheckshop.myshopify.com.

A vulnerability can arise is the hosted service expires, is deleted or was not correctly configured correctly
allowing a malicious attacker to register the service and hijack the domain.
data.synopsis:
External resources were audited for Subdomain and Service Take over vulnerabilities. This finding lists the audited
domains that were assessed during this scan.

data.solution: This finding is provided as information. No further action required.

data.description:
Amazon Web Services S3 Buckets were found linked from the target application. Each bucket was audited for
configuration vulnerabilities.

**Note**

AppCheck performs a passive supply chain audit of third-party resources reference by the target application. For
example, scripts imported from a third party host (e.g. A Cloud Service or CDN) are audited for vulnerabilities,
malicious content and misconfiguration that could be exploited to attack your application or its users.

As part of this audit, Amazon S3 buckets are checked for permissions flaws using AppChecks own AWS keys and by
issuing benign HTTP requests. It is possible that the effected resource was not configured by your organisation
but is rather part of a third-party solution that your application in some way references (e.g. links to or
imports from).
data.synopsis:
Amazon Web Services S3 Buckets were found linked from the target application. Each bucket was audited for
configuration vulnerabilities.

data.title: Discovered Email Addresses
data.description:
Email Addresses can be used by an attacker in an attempt to perform social engineering attacks and attack authentication systems. In many cases the portion of the email address before the [[code:@]] symbol is a valid username.

NOTICE: Email addresses at the [[code:@ptst.io]] domain are values that have been submitted as inputs during the scan. Their presence by this vulnerability indicates that a submitted value is reflected back to the user, which may be desired behaviour.
data.synopsis: Email addresses were harvested from the target application(s).

data.solution: Review whether or not such information should be published.

Ensure input from incoming client-side messages are sanitised in the
message handler before use.  For example, the message origin should be
verified.

data.solution: Although this CVE has been rejected, a code flaw does exist in this version. Customers are advised to upgrade to the latest version of Nginx. Nginx can be downloaded via many operating system package managers, or else via direct download from one of the HTTP mirrors listed on the Nginx website at [[http://nginx.org/en/download.html]].
data.title: INFO: Nginx < 1.23.2 - Memory Leak may lead to potential Denial of Service (DoS) Vulnerability (CVE-2022-3638)

details.Technical Details: This vulnerability was detected by comparing the detected version (1.19.6) against the affected versions reported by the vendor.
details.Messages:
---> GET /usage HTTP/1.1 Host: api.eks-dev.gcsepod.com Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8 Connection: close Referer: https://api.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/usage User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.132 Safari/537.36 Authorization: Bearer bc6244c7777e455a97a48e5989534d75 Accept-Encoding: gzip, identity <--- HTTP/1.1 502 Bad Gateway Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * Date: Mon, 15 Apr 2024 22:29:56 GMT Connection: Close Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 559 502 Bad Gateway

502 Bad Gateway

nginx/1.19.6

data.description:
NOTE: CVE has been withdraw, NVD states "This candidate was withdrawn by its CNA. Further investigation showed that it was not a security issue". Exploit of this vulnerability may require special circumstances or knowledge in order to actually exploit. Vulnerability has been reduced to INFO level impact/probability only.
 
Nginx (pronounced "engine x") is a web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, mail proxy and HTTP cache. Nginx is free and open-source software, released under the terms of the 2-clause BSD license. A large fraction of web servers use Nginx, often as a load balancer.

Nginx contains code ([[code:src/core/ngx_resolver.c]]) to perform resolution of both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses via DNS. A code change to the handling of address resolution when the "ipv4=" parameter was set to "off" potentially introduces a memory leak into the software due to the missing release of allocated memory. (In some languages, developers are responsible for tracking memory allocation and releasing the memory. If there are no more pointers or references to the memory, then it can no longer be tracked and identified for release.)

Most memory leaks result in general software reliability problems, but if an attacker can intentionally trigger a memory leak, the attacker might be able to launch a denial of service attack (by crashing or hanging the program) or take advantage of other unexpected program behaviour resulting from a low memory condition.

NOTE: in this instance the CNA (CVE Numbering Authority) that initially registered this CVE ID has requested that it be withdrawn/marked it as REJECTED. The reasons for this have not been published. Since the code flaw does exist, possible reasons for the REJECT flag include the vulnerability being valid but already registered under a duplicate CVE ID, it being withdrawn by the original requester (for example if further research determined the issue whilst a code flaw is not a vulnerability;), it being assigned incorrectly, the researcher decides to keep the vulnerability private, or some other administrative reason.


**References**

* [[http://hg.nginx.org/nginx/rev/0422365794f7]]

* [[https://github.com/nginx/nginx/commit/14341ce2377d38a268261e0fec65b6915ae6e95e]]

data.description:
Areas within the scanned application(s) were found to adapt content for
client devices based on User Agent strings.

This behaviour is interesting to the scanner since web applications may
present content to particular devices using a slightly or entirely
different code base, therefore extending the attack surface.

data.title: Mapped Attack Surface
data.description:
See details for a diagnostic listing of the enumerated attack surface.

**Please note that the information shown on the Details tab is a logical attack surface, which is not
the same thing as all the URLs that the scanner managed to find. Instead, it shows the targets that
follow a common pattern and, therefore, can be treated as a single target.**

The targets on the Details tab are grouped under a common "Response Structure" and also under a common "Target Structure".
What goes next is the description of these terms:

  - **Response Structure**: these targets have a common response structure.

    For example, two different blog posts will probably have different content but are served by the same app controller.

  - **Target Structure**: these targets share a common request structure and can be treated as a single target when trying different attack payloads.

**Example**

A web site has the following URLs:

  - https://www.example.com/products/first
  - https://www.example.com/products/second
  - https://www.example.com/pages/about-us


The scanner will create two response structures. The first response structure will cover URLs #1 and #2 because they are probably served by one
controller and produce a similar response. The second response structure will cover URL #3.

The scanner will also create one target structure: [URLTarget:https:www.example.com|80|p:{alpha}|p:{alpha}] as the input is the same URL for all
three pages. However, this target structure will be displayed twice (once under each response structure).
data.synopsis: See details for a diagnostic listing of the enumerated attack surface.
