data.solution:
When collecting Personally identifiable information from the user the following guidelines were provided by the UK's
Information Commissioners Office (ICO)

**Consent & Privacy Statement**

Ensure that you include a clear privacy statement that includes the the specific reason data will be stored. Consent
should be clear gained through positive opt-in.

*   Consent means offering individuals real choice and control. Genuine consent should put individuals in charge,
    build customer trust and engagement, and enhance your reputation.

*   Check your consent practices and your existing consents. Refresh your consents if they don't meet the GDPR
    standard.

*   Consent requires a positive opt-in. Don't use pre-ticked boxes or any other method of default consent.

*   Explicit consent requires a very clear and specific statement of consent.

*   Keep your consent requests separate from other terms and conditions.

*   Be specific and 'granular' so that you get separate consent for separate things. Vague or blanket consent is
    not enough.

*   Name any third party controllers who will rely on the consent.

*   Make it easy for people to withdraw consent and tell them how.

*   Keep evidence of consent - who, when, how, and what you told people.

*   Keep consent under review, and refresh it if anything changes.

*   Avoid making consent to processing a precondition of a service.

*   Public authorities and employers will need to take extra care to show that consent is freely given, and should avoid
    over-reliance on consent.


[[https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/lawful-basis-for-processing/consent/]]
data.title: GDPR: Possible PII form detected

details.Technical Details:
A form found at https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/teachers/usage appears to collect personally identifiable information (PII) from the user.

 **Form Page:** https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/teachers/usage

**Form Target:** https://members.eks-dev.gcsepod.com/teachers/usage

**Parameters:** email, start_date, end_date, subjects[]

data.description:
A form that appears to collect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) was detected. This does not constitute a
specific vulnerability, but rather is reported to aid in GDPR readiness and compliance.

AppCheck identifies PII collection forms based on the input fields and text within the form. Forms with several
text fields including inputs that request email addresses are flagged. False positives are minimised by ignoring
authentication and password reset forms. However occasionally false positives may occur. This happens when a form
matches the rule defined within this check but is not actually collecting PII data from the user. If this is the
case here, setting the finding to "False Positive" within the Workflow tab will remove it from the report and prevent
it being flagged in future scans.
data.synopsis:
A form that appears to collect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) was detected. This does not constitute a
specific vulnerability, but rather is reported to aid in GDPR readiness and compliance.

data.description:
The [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute specifies how the browser should handle the cookie in cross-site requests.
It is intended to mitigate cross site information leakage and some protection against cross-site request forgery
attacks.

To be considered the same site, the scheme and the domain (excluding sub domain) must match. For example
[[code:https://www.example.com]], [[code:https://foobar.example.com]], [[code:https://example.com]],
and [[code:https://example.com:8080] are the same site, however [[code:http://www.example.com]] is a different
site.
This is an important distinction from same origin (where the scheme, domain, and port must match), since any
vulnerability allowing the execution of attacker controlled JavaScript can be abused to bypass site based defences
such as the [[code:SameSite]] cookie attribute.

The [[code:SameSite]] attribute may be set to [[code:Lax]], [[code:Strict]], or [[code:None]], if unspecified the
default is [[code:Lax]].

**Lax**

Browsers will send the cookie in cross-site requests which have the [[code:GET]] method and where triggered by a
top level navigation by the user (e.g. clicking a link). The cookie is not sent in cross-site [[code:POST]]
requests or background requests (e.g. from image references, iframes, or scripts).

Note that some web servers and frameworks will accept [[code:POST]] or [[code:GET]] requests which can be abused
to bypass this protection, it is therefore important to verify that only [[code:POST]] requests are accepted for
requests that modify state or data (in line with best practices) before relying on this cookie attribute.

**Strict**

Browsers will not send the cookie in any cross-site requests. This is the recommended option for any cookies that
permit authenticated access to resources as it is the most secure option, however it may negatively impact the user
experience in cases where cross-site functionality is intended.

**None**

Browsers will send the cookie in all cross-site requests no matter how the request was triggered or which site
triggered the request. This is the least secure option and the default behaviour of browsers before the
introduction of the [[code:SameSite]] attribute, leaving the site more susceptible to cross site attacks and
leakage.
There are some instances where [[code:SameSite:None]] is desirable such as when the cookie is intended to be used
from a third party context and doesn't grant any privileges.
Note for the [[code:SameSite:None]] attribute to be effective the [[code:Secure]] attribute must also be specified.
data.synopsis:
The [[code:SameSite=None]] cookie attribute instructs the browser to send the cookie in all cross site requests.
This can leave the application more vulnerable to cross-site attacks such as cross site request forgery.

data.solution:
Review the usage of cookies with the [[code:SameSite=None]] attribute to determine if they can be set to
[[code:SameSite=Strict]] or [[code:SameSite=Lax]] to take advantage of the more rigorous security the browser then
provides.
data.title: Cookie with SameSite=None attribute

data.title: Cloud Provider Identified
data.description:
Checks whether the target system is hosted on a commonly used cloud platform provider.

During the assessment, it was observed that the target system wwas hosted on a cloud platform. It is important to note that conducting any scanning or testing activities on cloud-based systems without explicit permission from the cloud provider may violate their terms of service and could lead to legal and ethical consequences.

Cloud environments often involve shared responsibilities between the provider and the client, requiring authorized access for security evaluations. Therefore, obtaining permission from the cloud provider is paramount before initiating any scanning or testing procedures to ensure compliance with ethical standards and maintain a responsible approach to the assessment.
data.synopsis: Checks whether the target system is hosted on a commonly used cloud platform provider.

details.Technical Details:
The following table summarises the state of connectivity to the target host, which can be used to troubleshoot any networking problems with Appcheck support.



+-----------------+--------+
| Check           | Status |
+=================+========+
| ICMP echo reply | False  |
+-----------------+--------+
| ARP response    | False  |
+-----------------+--------+
| Open TCP ports  | True   |

data.description:
Appcheck connectivity checks were completed successfully. The results provide insights into potential networking issues encountered during the scan, aiding in understanding why the scan may have succeeded or failed.

The results of the connectivity checks serve as indicators rather than definitive determinants of the scan's success. While these checks encompass various networking factors such as ICMP response, ARP response, open TCP and UDP ports, and the number of hops to the host, a successful scan can still occur even if some of these indicators return negative results. These indicators provide valuable insights into potential networking issues that may have influenced the scan's outcome.
data.synopsis: Appcheck connectivity checks were completed successfully. The results provide insights into potential networking issues encountered during the scan, aiding in understanding why the scan may have succeeded or failed.

data.description:
This check analyzes the certificates exposed on open SSL/TLS ports of the remote host, providing insights into their details. It helps in understanding the cryptographic keys, expiration dates, issuer details, and subject information of the certificates, aiding in assessing the security posture of the network's SSL/TLS implementation.

Reviewing certificates across your estate is crucial as it unveils potential vulnerabilities stemming from misconfigurations or outdated certificates. This check offers a detailed examination of SSL/TLS certificates on all open ports, shedding light on key details such as expiry dates, issuers, and cryptographic keys. Understanding these aspects aids in fortifying your network against certificate-based vulnerabilities, ensuring robust security measures.

details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

- CVE-2020-11022

data.description: In jQuery versions greater than or equal to 1.2 and before 3.5.0, passing HTML from untrusted sources - even after sanitizing it - to one of jQuery's DOM manipulation methods (i.e. [[code:.html()]], [[code:.append()]], and others) may execute untrusted code.

data.solution:
In fixed versions, jQuery only deems the input to be HTML if it explicitly starts with the '[[code:<]]' character, limiting exploitability only to attackers who can control the beginning of a string, which is far less common.

Update to the latest version.

This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

- CVE-2012-6708

data.description:
jQuery before 1.9.0 is vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The [[code:jQuery(strInput)]] function does not differentiate selectors from HTML in a reliable fashion.

In vulnerable versions, jQuery determined whether the input was HTML by looking for the '[[code:<]]' character anywhere in the string, giving attackers more flexibility when attempting to construct a malicious payload.

data.solution: Update to the latest version.

details.CVEs:
This vulnerability covers the following CVEs:

- CVE-2019-11358

data.description:
jQuery before 3.4.0, as used in Drupal, Backdrop CMS, and other products, mishandles [[code:jQuery.extend(true, {}, ...)]] because of [[code:Object.prototype]] pollution. If an unsanitized source object contained an enumerable [[code:__proto__ property]], it could extend the native [[code:Object.prototype]].

The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype.

By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the product depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as [[code:hasOwnProperty()]], [[code:toString()]] or [[code:valueOf()]]).

This weakness is usually exploited by using a special attribute of objects called proto, constructor or prototype. Such attributes give access to the object prototype. This weakness is often found in code that assigns object attributes based on user input, or merges or clones objects recursively.

data.solution: Update to the latest version.

data.description:
The remote host's hostname is not consistent with the original resolved IP address discovered at the start of the assessment.

The hostname or DNS entry of this machine inconsistently resolved to different IP addresses. This could be the result of a load balancer, DNS round robin or hosting on a content delivery network which exists between the scanner and the target.

data.description:
The issue summary highlights the discovery of various Common Platform Enumerations (CPEs) during the engagement, listing the range of software and systems present in the environment. This enumeration provides insight into the technologies utilized, aiding in vulnerability assessment and prioritization efforts. Identifying these CPEs also assist in understanding the attack surface and potential security risks associated with the discovered platforms.

Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) is a standardized method of describing and identifying software applications, operating systems, and hardware devices. It provides a structured naming scheme to represent unique configurations, enabling consistent identification and management of IT assets across different organizations and systems.

details.Technical Details:
This finding was detected by submitting a request to the server then analysing the response to determine that the following conditions are met:

* The following word was matched in the response: <form 

* The following word was matched in the response: </form> 

* The following word was matched in the response: <button 



**Vulnerability Information**

+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+
| Property    | Value                                             |
+=============+===================================================+
| severity    | info                                              |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+
| reference   | https://github.com/dirtycoder0124/formcrawler     |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+
| tags        | form,misc                                         |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+
| description | A template to detect HTML Forms in page response. |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+
| name        | Form Detection                                    |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------+

data.description:
A request was submitted to the application to detect a known security flaw, misconfiguration or information disclosure. Based on the response it appears the remote system is vulnerable.

**Vulnerability Description**

A template to detect HTML Forms in page response.
